deck:
Phaedos was the planet where the Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers got their Ninja Ranger powers in Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers: The Movie. It is not known if Phaedos exists in the TV show's continuity too.

The planet is also the home of the ancient ruins of the Ninjetti Temple.
description:
Phaedos was on first sight a wasteland planet, but as shown later, there is a vast ocean and also a great jungle, called the Niola Jungle.

The ground is covered with the skeletal remains of those who tried and failed to obtain the Great Power.

There is only one known person living on Phaedos - Dulcea. She is the Master Warrior of Phaedos and guards the planet with her life. There is also a place in the jungle where there are some skeletons of dinosaur-like creatures. When the Rangers cross this place, one of the skeletons comes to life and either tries to eat the Rangers or stop them from reaching the Great Power. It's unclear if it's a reanimated skeleton or if the creature only resembles one to trick its prey and enemies.

The original draft of the script describes eel-like creatures called squirbs.

There are also the Rock Guardians which guard the Temple of Power in the middle of the Niola Jungle. They attack the Rangers and are the toughest to beat before receiving the Great Power.

It is not known exactly where Phaedos is placed in the Milky Way Galaxy, only that the planet was distant and the journey to it takes a lot of power. In an early version of the script, Alpha 5 said it's located somewhere in the Hyperion Constellation.

issue_credits.name: The Official Comic Book Adaptation of the Hit Film
The Official Photo Comic Adaptation of the Hit Film!

movies.name: Mighty Morphing Power Rangers The Movie

name: Phaedos

deck: Home planet of Zordon.
description: Eltar is Zordon's homeplanet. Upon his release from the interdimensional timewarp that Rita Repulsa put him in, he returned to Eltar with Alpha 5 to reunite with his relatives. The Phantom Ranger was also said to be of Eltarian origin by Divatox, though the Phantom is shown to reside on his own planet in "In Space". In the end of Turbo it was revealed that there was a war occurring on Eltar and Zordon & Alpha 5 had even built robotic clones of the 2nd team of Turbo Rangers to help in the war, in the final episodes of the show Dimitria along with the Blue Centurion traveled to Eltar to help out. The planet was conquered by the United Alliance of Evil during the events of Chase Into Space, the final episodes of Power Rangers Turbo culminating in the capture of Zordon. In that episode, Justin revealed that the Turbo Rangers' powers were derived from Eltar, and shut down when the planet was conquered

The Necropolis of Wakanda is where the T'Challa reigns as the King of the Dead. He has been placed in charge over all deceased Black Panthers by the Panther Goddess and is in tune with their spirits.

deck: Setting for C.S. Lewis' Chronicles of Narnia series of novels
description:
Narnia is a fantasy storyworld created by theologist and writer C.S. Lewis featured in his seven-part Chronicles of Narnia books. The books use many of the conventions of young adult quest fantasy, but there is also a strong Christian allegorical subtext. They were originally published annually between 1950-1956.

The first of the two books were adapted into movies, but the franchise apparently stopped there. The series includes:

The Magician's Nephew- Harper Collins established a reading order for the books which C.S. Lewis himself later endorsed. In spite of The Magician's Nephew usually being packaged as the sixth book in the series, the new order placed it first because of its chronology.
The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe- The book that most of the world regard as the first in this series. In post-war Britain, four orphans are sent to live with their eccentric relative and chance upon a doorway to Narnia via a plain looking wardrobe. They soon become involved with a war between Aslan the Lion and the White Witch for the soul of the land. The first of the series to be made into a film.
The Horse and His Boy- While this book is generally packaged as the fifth in the series, Harper Collins placed it as the third, again due to continuity issues in the series.
Prince Caspian- The children return to Narnia to help its rightful ruler. The second in the series to be adapted into film.
The Voyage of the Dawn Treader- Prince Caspian sails to find the seven lords banished by Miraz.
The Silver Chair- Caspian's son is the focus of this novel.
The Last Battle- The conclusion of the series, in which Aslan returns and the aforementioned allegories are perhaps most obvious.

In comics, the films have been parodied in Mad Magazine, but the books themselves have yet to be adapted into a graphic format. C.S. Lewis died in 1963.
name: Narnia

volume_credits.name: The Graphic Canon of Children's Literature: The World's Greatest Kids' Lit as Comics and Visuals

deck: The planet Pandora is the main setting for the Borderlands universe.
description:
A barren, desolate world filled with hostile creatures, Pandora derives sunlight indirectly from the reflection of its moon. Pandora has a 90-hour day and takes ten Earth years to orbit its sun (one winter is seven earth years and a summer is three earth years). Pandora was first settled by humans during a winter season, when much of its wildlife was hibernating. After seven earth years, the warming climate in that region has resulted in most of the known native wildlife (excluding rakk hives and some other unknown or undiscovered species) waking from their hibernation, all of which are hostile to Pandora's new human settlers.

The main events of Borderlands and Borderlands 2 take place on Pandora.
name: Pandora

deck: Headquarted of the Time Variance Authority.
description:
Headquarters of the Time Variance Authority.

It houses the operational desks of the time continuity supervisors, prison cells for the villains that mix or put in danger the continuity of the events, and other facilities.

It is the operative base of the Justice agents who run the timestream to defend and correct the problems.
name: Trans-temporal Offices

deck: Sacred city of the League of Assassins, built over centuries by Ra's al Ghul.
description:
'Eth Alth'eban (Arabic for Snake's Nest) was a sacred city where the League of Assassins was born and served as their secret headquarters hidden from the prying eyes. This wondrous paradise served as the basis for what Ra's Al Ghul desired for the rest of the world. At some point, the Untitled became a threat to the League who placed magical wards to protect their home from their god-like power. However, they sensed the dangers posed by those beings and thus Bronze Tiger sought out Jason Todd as it was determined that he was the only person capable of defeating this threat. As a result, they abducted him and brought him to the hidden city where they asked him to lead them against the Untitled.

Creation

'Eth Alth'eban was created by James Tynion IV and Julius Gopez in Red Hood and the Outlaws #21. The city's name is Arabic for "Snake's Nest".


Writer's Note

James Tynion IV pitched the concept of the city to DC as follows:

"Deep in the Arabian Peninsula lies the hidden city of ETH ALTHEBAN, the ancient stronghold city of The League of Assassins. Its hidden in a labyrinthine series of canyons in the middle of the desert. Its entrance should be reminiscent of the entrance to the Al Khazne temple near Petra (which you might find familiar from Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade) The primary difference is that there should be accents of copper throughout, including gigantic copper doors. The design should also have a snake theme, to it with decorative snakelike flourishes. It should look ancient, aside from the copper which is polished and shining. The whole entrance is carved into the wall Its been standing for generations, hidden away from the world.Inside these walls is another story altogether After proceeding through the doors and opening a high tech series of barricades, you find yourself somewhere spectacular Its an underground technological eco-paradise, with the architectural styles of a pre-Islam Arabia. Its an unspeakably massive setting, with a huge artificial sun in the roofs of the cavern. Its a full city under the ground, filled with the most dangerous people who have ever lived.

This is Ras al Ghuls utopian paradise. This is what he has wanted to bring to the world for all these years A place of magic, incredibly advanced technology, and nature, all together in a small bubble of paradise.Imagine it co-existing with luscious, tropical vegetation and wildlife Hanging gardens, tropical birds, and crystal clear waterfalls built into the seams of the place Its like a beautiful city built into a nature preserve.

On top of this, there should be evidence of incredibly advanced technology, mixed in with the ancient, colorful architecture and wildlife. There should be smart-glass displays in the windows, and old style markets selling the most dangerous high tech weapons known to man (right across the aisle from a fruit-stand). The population of the city should not be predominantly Arabic, but more pan-global. Every person in there is a killer, or someone involved with the death industry. Showing the market, we should see 5-Star Generals in full regalia walking side by side with ninjas, next to people in suits of fully robotic killer body-armor. Theyre all enjoying the freedom of the place.

Everyone should have a hint of danger to them, but there shouldnt be a unifying code of dress or anything like it. It needs to be fluid and strange and contradictory in its elements to keep every moment visually dynamic.Also: In terms of the foot soldiers of the League of Assassins, I want to keep the Ninja Man-Bats So we should always see a few of them flying around the place, particularly in the wide shots of the spires and towers of the place. We can see them flying around, or resting on the rooftops and minarets. Its an added touch of color that I think really elevates the entire place.In the center of the city there should be a giant statue of Ras al Ghul holding the artificial sun at the roof of the cavern, towering over the buildings and spires. At the feet of the statue, there should be a large, ornamental fountain that has been sealed up with a polished copper lid with ancient marking and runes in Arabic, Chinese, Cyrillic and Celtic characters.The largest building should be like a palace, directly behind the statue of Ras Al Ghul and the fountain beneath it. This is where Bronze Tiger and the ruling council of the League of Assassins has been running the show since Talia left to wage her battle with Batman in Gotham City."
name: 'Eth Alth'eban

deck: A S.H.I.E.L.D. outpost in New York.
description:
Looking like an innocent barbershop, Sam's Barbershop was actually S.H.I.E.L.D. Outpost in the Lower East Side of New York City with a S.H.I.E.L.D. facility located in the sub-basement levels. It was used for a time to help train the S.H.I.E.L.D. Super-Agents but it was abandoned following an attack from the Corporation.

Years later when the Red Skull stole S.H.I.E.L.D.'s Helicarrier, S.H.I.E.L.D. returned to operating out of Sam's Barbershop as their main headquarters. After reclaiming the Helicarrier from the Skull, S.H.I.E.L.D. again abandoned the Barbershop entirely.

The empty Outpost was used for a time by Winter Soldier and Wolverine following Captain America's death. It was later one of many safehouses used by Nick Fury and his Secret Warriors until Ares discovered and subsequently demolished most of it.

In Other Media

Sam's Barbershop was featured in an episode of Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes. Nick Fury brings a recently revived Captain America there and presents him with some equipment, including a motorcycle.

deck: A haunted house.
description:
Origin

The Trask Mansion was the site of over a hundred murders committed by a group of wealthy individuals. Multiple members of the Trask Family were involved in every sort of murder imaginable, from cannibalizing the bodies of patients, hunting homeless people on the grounds of the mansion, or luring men into their bedroom in order to kill them.

Creation

The Trask Mansion was created by Joshua Williamson for his comic Ghosted.
name: Trask Mansion

deck: A survivalist compound created to protect its citizens for the upcoming apocalypse.

Creation

Safe Haven was created by Sheltered writer Ed Brisson and artist John Christmas.

deck: Location Setting for Six-Gun Gorilla.
description: Location setting for Six-Gun Gorilla. The Blister was colonized by humans sometime in the 22nd century, it quickly became a hotly-contested source of fertile land and natural resources long ago exhausted on Earth. Earth based physics do not function normally, there is no combustion or electricity. Daily fire-storms are a constant threat.
name: The Blister

deck: An entire floor of an apartment building Danny Rand gave to the Avengers to use as their base after the Masters of Evil destroyed Doctor Strange's Sanctum Sanctorum.
description:
An entire floor of an apartment building owned by the Rand Corporation which was rented out by Samuel Sterns. With Sterns' assets seized, Danny Rand decided to use the space as the Avengers base of operations.

"Avengers Apartment" (as dubbed by Clint Barton) didn't serve as their base for too long, with the team abandoning it after the Secret Invasion had ended and were forced into hiding due to Norman Osborn's Dark Reign.
name: Avengers Apartment

deck: An old mansion in New York City which has hosted the Hellfire Club for many decades. It had been abonnend for a number of years, but appears to be in use again.
description:
Origin

The Hellfire Club Mansion was founded in the 19th century and is one of the older building in New York City. It had been used as the headqarters of the Hellfire Club, a group of wealthy industrialists bent on world-domination.

Creation

The Hellfire Club Mansion was created by Chris Claremont and John Byrne and first appeared in (Uncanny) X-Men issue 129 (1980).

Major Story Arcs

The Dark Phoenix Saga

The Mansion had been part of the Hellfire Club for many decades, even in recent times when most of the memebers where wealthy mutants. The mansion played a key role during the Dark Phoenix Saga, as X-Men-member Phoenix was tricked into entering the place by Mastermind, where she was brainwashed in believing she was also a member of the club. The X-Men intervened but where defeated and captured inside the mansion. After the Phoenix became Dark Phoenix, the X-Men where freed and the place was wrecked following the ensuing battle.

Hide Out

Afterwards, the mansion was used for a number of years as residence of the Hellions, and for social parties but had been abandoned some years later. It briefly served as a hideout for the Avengers during Dark Reign.

It also briefly served as a hideout for a group of All-New X-Men after Cyclops' hideout-base, the New Charles Xavier School for Mutants (the former Weapon X Facility) was abondonned by the team.

Uncanny X-Men

After the events of Secret Wars, Magneto's lead X-Men find out that the mansion is once more in use by the club.

deck: The main base of MACH-IV and Songbird's Thunderbolts team. Located in Brooklyn near a naval shipping yard.
description:
When Abe Jenkins reformed the Thunderbolts he rented the warehouse using money and funding from Baron Strucker and HYDRA. Later Speed Demon would steal money to help finance the rent on their hideout.

The warehouse was destroyed during an attack by the Squadron Sinister and the team relocated to the Richmond Ranch.

deck: Using the Moonstones, Zemo created openings in space, taking patches of real places from the real world, and connected them between folded space.
description: The Folding Castle was used as a base by Zemo's Thunderbolts and later both Songbird and Zemo's Thunderbolts teams as well as the Thunderbolts Army. Each member's quarters was made just for them, such as Radioactive Man who's quarters resembled a Chinese monastary, and were all connected to the same "hub".
name: Folding Castle

deck: A small town in Colorado, birthplace of Molecule Man and subsequently effectively taken over by him in later life.
description:
Dinosaur has/had a population of 319 people and something of an affinity for the extinct animal they share a namesake with.

Owen Reece was born in Dinosaur and spend his youth there, eventually becoming the immensely powerful superhuman known as the Molecule Man, the sometimes villain and sometimes protector of the Earth.

Sometime after escaping the Raft during Secret Invasion, Molecule Man returned to Dinosaur and decided to use his power to take control of the remote town and live in solitude. When visitors began disappearing, the world got wind of something sinister in Dinosaur and the Avengers were deployed.

Easily defeating his attackers, Molecule Man realized he couldn't kill them because that would incur further investigation when all he wanted was to be left alone. Molecule Man resolved to relinquish control over Dinosaur and return everything to normal, and after doing so, was murdered by Sentry.
name: Dinosaur

description: A middle-eastern city that has a lousy sultan, a palace, developing economy and a dam.
name: Wanatolia

deck: Airan Island or "airantou" is the name given to this unknown island 130 years ago by the current inhabitants. It's surrounded by dangerous whirlpools that prevent escape.
description:
Airan Island (, Airan-t) is a location from the Nagasarete Airantou series that was written by Takeshi Fujishiro. The series first began serialization Square Enix's Monthly Shnen Gangan in January 2002. It first appeared in Nagasarete Airantou Volume 1 CH. 1 "Cast Away".

The name of the island was selected to name after the ship that the survivors traveled on before it sunk. The name of the ship was called "The Island". Using the Japanese katakana, the English word for 'Island' would be pronounced as "Airanto". The Kanji added to the name of an island() can be pronounced as "tou". They simply removed the "to" from the pronunciation of the word 'island' and replaced it with the "tou" from the Japanese word for island.

In Japanese, "airan-tou" could mean Blue Orchard Island, but the ship they were traveling on was not called "Blue Orchard".
name: Airan Island

deck: Walled city-state in Hyrkania on the Eastern shore of the Vilayet Sea.

issue_credits.name: The Monster of the Monoliths and Other Stories

name: Makkalet

deck: Kingdom of Turan is rising in barbaric splendor on the south-western shores of the great inland sea Vilayet.
description:
"Yezdigerd, king of Turan, was the mightiest monarch in the world. In his palace in the great port city of Aghrapur was heaped the plunder of empires. His fleets of purple-sailed war galleys had made Vilayet an Hyrkanian lake. The dark-skinned people of Zamora paid him tribute, as did the eastern provinces of Koth. The Shemites bowed to his rule as far west as Shushan. (...) His gilt-helmeted swordsmen had trampled hosts under their horses' hoofs, and walled cities went up in flames at his command. In the glutted slave markets of Aghrapur, Sultanapur, Khawarizm, Shapur and Khorusun, women were sold for three small silver coins -- blond Brythunians, tawny Stygians, dark-haired Zamorians, ebon Kushites, olive-skinned Shemites."

Robert E. Howard: "The Devil In Iron"

Overview:

Also called the Sunrise Empire, Turan is a nation with lands first extending only along the western reaches of the Vilayet Sea, but eventually stretching westward over the steppes and desert, reaching the border of Zamora by the time of Conan's reign.

Turan was the wealthiest realm west of Khitai, with the possible exception of Vendhya. It had many ports along the Eastern and western shores of the Vilayet and was mistress of the inland sea. Its capital, Aghrapur, had a huge, magnificent palace called the Sunrise Court.

The ambitious Turanians (often calling themselves Hyrkanians, after their ancient race) made forays in all directions as they attempted to enlarge their empire. They had usurped most of the important caravan cities of the Eastern Desert by Conan's time, crowded the eastern frontier of Zamora, taken over the caravan route to the Far East with the assistance of their kinsmen, the Hyrkanians of the far eastern steppe, and even invaded Vendhya. Their strongest monarch, Yezdigerd, exacted tribute from eastern Shem and Brythunia and fought successful battles with the armies of Hyperborea and Stygia.

Inhabited by the Hyrkanian race dark and generally tall and slender.

Between the inland sea and the eastern borders of the native western kingdoms lie vast expanses of steppes and in the extreme north and extreme south, deserts.

Noted for bandits. Powerful Turanian bow kills at five hundred paces.

Women wear veils. Silk is very common here, and it is worn by all classes of people from nobles and soldiers to commoners and slaves.

Slavery is very common in Turan. Some of the largest slave markets in all the world exist here.

NOTE: In many ways Turan is analogous to an amalgamation of the ancient Persian Empire and the medieval Ottoman Empire.

name: Turan

deck: City in Turan (Hyboria).
description: Once a bright and prosperous city, Yaralet was lately oppressed by the evil rule of Munthassem Khan, who turned from a gentle and wise satrap to a cruel and savage autocrat after gaining possession of the Hand of Nergal.

issue_credits.name: Flesh for the Gods of the Night

name: Yaralet

deck: Located is in eastern Hyboria. Magic is prevalent and they are constantly at war with Kambuja which lies to the south.
description:
"Then there were camels, and yellow-skinned men who wore silk robes and spoke in a weird tongue. (...) He was a magician from far Khitai, returning to his native kingdom after a journey to Stygia. He took me with him to purple-towered Paikang, its minarets rising amid the vine-festooned jungles of bamboo, and there I grew to womanhood under his teaching. Age had steeped him deep in black wisdom, not weakened his powers of evil. Many things he taught me --"

-- Robert E. Howard:

"A Witch Shall Be Born"

Gazetteer of the Hyborian World

Note - Khitai is roughly analogous to an amalgamation of ancient China and ancient to feudal Japan both culturally and geographically.

issue_credits.name: Volume XII: Swords Against the Jade Kingdom

name: Khitai

deck: The many-towered, glittering capital city of Turan.
description: A massive seaport on the Vilayet Sea, probably the most glorious of all the cites of the age. Aghrapur is the most populous city west of the Vilayet, home to 160,000 people. No city of the world is as luxurious. Originally a Zamorian city before the Hykanians came, Aghrapur is now a glittering Turanain city of haggling merchants creating a din of barter, slant-eyed wenches brazenly posturing, canopied litters bearing wealthy, discreetly veiled princess and conquering slavers presenting nude slave girls on the auction block.
name: Aghrapur

deck: A desolate wasteland of bogs and plains which serves as a buffer state between the barbaric North and the civilized kingdoms to the South.
name: Border Kingdom

volume_credits.name: The Handbook of the Conan Universe

deck: A cold and dark dimension composed of Darkforce Matter.
description:
The Darkforce Dimension is used heavily by Cloak as well as Blackout and Shroud. Other characters also have access to the Darkforce Dimension or some control over Darkforce Matter.

Notable characters who have spent some time trapped within the Darkforce Dimension include: Captain Marvel, Moonstone, Smuggler and Photon. The latter of whom was banished there after being broken up into several pieces and scatted across the timestream by Baron Zemo to ensure he would never be able to return.

issue_credits.name: Lost And Found: Part Two of Two

name: Darkforce Dimension
